awd_titl_txt: Designing Our Tomorrow: Mobilizing the Next Generation of Engineers
awd_abstract_narration:
This Innovations in Development project is funded by the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program, which seeks to advance new approaches to, and evidence-based understanding of, the design and development of STEM learning in informal environments. This includes providing multiple pathways for broadening access to and engagement in STEM learning experiences, advancing innovative research on and assessment of STEM learning in informal environments, and developing understandings of deeper learning by participants.

The Designing  Our  Tomorrow project will develop a framework for creating exhibit-based engineering design challenges and expand an existing model of facilitation for use in engineering exhibits. The project seeks to broaden participation in engineering and build capacity within the informal science education (ISE) field while raising public awareness of the importance of sustainable engineering design practices. The project focuses on girls aged 9-14 and their families and is co-developed with culturally responsive strategies to ensure the inclusion and influence of families from Latino communities. The project will conduct research resulting in theory-based measures of engineering proficiencies within an exhibit context and an exhibit facilitation model for the topic area of engineering.  Based on the research, the project will develop an engineering design challenge framework for developing design challenges within an exhibit context. As the context for research, the project will develop a bilingual English/Spanish 2,000-square foot traveling exhibition designed to engage youth and families in engineering design challenges that advance their engineering proficiencies from beginner to more informed, supported by professional development modules and a host-site training workshop introducing strategies for facilitating family engineering experiences within a traveling exhibition. The project is a collaboration of Oregon Museum of Science and Industry with the Biomimicry Institute, Adelante Mujeres, and the Fleet Science Center. 

Designing  Our  Tomorrow builds on a theory-based engineering teaching framework and several previous NSF-funded informal education projects to engage families in compelling design challenges presented through the lens of sustainable design exemplified by biomimicry.  Through culturally-responsive co-development and research strategies to include members of Latino communities and provide challenges that highlight the altruistic, creative, personally relevant, and collaborative aspects of engineering, the Designing  Our  Tomorrow exhibition showcases engineering as an appealing career option for women and helps families support each other's engineering proficiencies. To better understand and promote engineering learning in an ISE setting, the project will conduct two research studies to inform and iteratively develop effective strategies. In the first study, measurement development will build on prior research and practice to design credible and reliable measures of engineering proficiency, awareness, and collaboration, as well as protocols for use in exhibit development and the study of facilitation at engineering exhibits, and future research. The second study will explore the effects of facilitation on the experience outcomes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Core to Designing Our Tomorrow: Mobilizing the Next Generation of Engineers (DOT) is recognition that community members can, and do, leverage engineering practices to address grand challenges our world faces today. Co-developed by Oregon Museum of Science and Industry, Adelante Mujeres, Biomimicry Institute, and Fleet Science Center, the six-year project was implemented by a large, collaborative team. This team employed research, evaluation, and innovative thinking to better understand how girls ages 9-14 and their families engage with engineering practices at interactive design exhibits. These activities resulted in team members learning to co-develop new exhibits that support families in exercising more nuanced engineering practices. Additionally, DOT provided insights on how caregivers and educators might have conversations about the value of engineering practices in day-to-day life--particularly in addressing community challenges. Throughout DOT, the team prioritized culturally responsive and co-development approaches, with leadership and influence from members of Latine communities at every stage of the project. To help the informal engineering education field better support community members and broaden participation in engineering, products include reports, articles, and presentations on research and evaluation, plus online professional development modules for exhibit developers, designers, and educators.

Broader Impacts. DOT's impact is most visible when girls and their families exercise more nuanced engineering practices while engaging with Creatividad silvestre | Wild Creativity, a 2,500 square foot, co-developed traveling exhibit. The award-winning, environmentally green exhibit is the first interactive biomimicry exhibit; content includes biomimicry fundamentals and innovations, inspirations from nature, and design challenges. The Spanish-forward experience encourages community building and creative thinking while looking to nature to inspire real-world solutions.

Amidst the challenges of COVID lockdown team members learned new ways to use online tools for collaborative exhibit development and gathering public input on exhibits. The DOT project served as a place for team members, many from Latine communities, to learn and leverage new roles including exhibit co-developer, co-designer, evaluator, storytelling ambassador, researcher, and principal investigator. The knowledge and skills gained from this project are being invested in new projects--for example, team members are now working with a Colaborativo from a local Latine community who will create climate conversation and action exhibits. 

Advancing knowledge. DOT contributed to the advancements of knowledge through the creation of deliverables such as two research studies, an exhibit, professional development modules, and evaluation reports.

The two research studies helped guide and inform many aspects of the project. The first, the study of Collaborative Practices at Interactive Engineering Challenge Exhibits (C-PIECE Study), describes a theory- and evidence-based tool, the C-PIECE Framework that informal engineering education professionals can use to understand how visitors can exercise more nuanced engineering practices at exhibits. This framework informed: 1) Creatividad silvestre | Wild Creativity, 2) the Design Challenge Resource Collection (Developer and Designer PD), 3) Educator Professional Development modules (Educator PD), and 4) a second study, Conversation Participants' Choices and Connections on the Topic of Engineering Practices and Usefulness in Day-to-day Life (EP&UDL Study). The EP&UDL Study was co-developed with caregivers of girls ages 9 to 14 and focused on interpersonal conversations and storytelling about the engineering practices exercised at the DOT exhibits and their usefulness in day-to-day life. This research resulted in the theory- and evidence-based Model of Conversation Participants' Choices and Connections on the Topic of Engineering Practices and Usefulness in Day-to-day Life (EP&UDL Model). This model can help informal engineering education practitioners and researchers communicate with the public about engineering practices.

The exhibit, Creatividad silvestre | Wild Creativity, incorporated research on 1) how to present biomimicry in ways that would engage girls, and 2) how to design activities that allow visitor groups to exercise more nuanced engineering practices. The exhibit and its use of research are well documented, offering the field an exhibit model that exercises sustainable, informed engineering practices in the context of biomimicry.

There were two main professional development resources created during the DOT study. One is the Design Challenge Resource Collection (DCRC)--a set of nine modules with tools and approaches useful for creating non-facilitated engineering design challenge exhibits. These modules help exhibit designers develop exhibits that are engaging, relevant, and accessible to participants. The other resource, the Educator PD, is a set of three web-based, bilingual modules for individuals and teams. The Educator PD is designed to help practitioners foster communications in which caregivers think of engineering as a familiar and useful set of practices in their lives. 

Evaluation activities were conducted throughout the project and provided professionals with additional insights. For example, front-end evaluation and research with Latina youth helped guide the development of the exhibit's sustainability and biomimicry experiences. Summative evaluation on the exhibit confirmed visitors' use of more nuanced engineering practices in Creatividad silvestre | Wild Creativity. All project reports and modules are available on the OMSI website and informalscience.org.
